1.name: Left Cerebral White Matter
structure: Composed of myelinated axons connecting different regions of the cerebral cortex with each other and with subcortical structures

Contains projection fibers (corona radiata, internal capsule), commissural fibers (corpus callosum, anterior commissure), and association fibers (superior/inferior longitudinal fasciculi, uncinate fasciculus)
Myelin is produced by oligodendrocytes and creates a lipid-rich insulating sheath that increases conduction velocity
Organized into discrete bundles or tracts with specific connectivity patterns and functions
function: Enables rapid, efficient neural signal transmission across distant brain regions
Facilitates integration of sensory, motor, and cognitive processes through interconnected networks
Supports neuroplasticity through activity-dependent myelination and structural remodeling
Integrity of white matter tracts is essential for cognitive processing speed and executive function

2.name: Left Cerebral Cortex
structure: Outer 2-4mm gray matter layer covering the cerebral hemisphere, organized into six cellular layers (I-VI)
Contains approximately 16 billion neurons with complex dendritic arborizations and synaptic connections
Organized into functional regions including primary sensory/motor areas and association cortices
Characterized by gyri (ridges) and sulci (grooves) that increase surface area without increasing cranial volume
function: Processes and integrates sensory information into perceptions, thoughts, and behavioral responses
Left hemisphere specializes in language processing, analytical reasoning, and right-sided motor control
Hierarchical processing from primary sensory areas to unimodal and then multimodal association areas
Supports higher cognitive functions including working memory, attention, decision-making, and consciousness

3.name: Left Lateral Ventricle
structure: C-shaped CSF-filled cavity within the cerebral hemisphere, consisting of central body and three horns (anterior, posterior, inferior)
Lined by ependymal cells forming the ventricular epithelium
Contains choroid plexus tissue that produces approximately 400-500ml of CSF daily
Connected to the third ventricle via the interventricular foramen of Monro
function: Forms part of the ventricular system for CSF production, circulation, and drainage
CSF provides mechanical protection, buoyancy (reducing effective brain weight by ~97%), and metabolic support
Facilitates clearance of metabolic waste products from the brain parenchyma
Ventricular enlargement serves as an important biomarker for neurodegenerative conditions and hydrocephalus

4.name: Left Thalamus
structure: Egg-shaped gray matter structure forming the dorsal part of the diencephalon
Organized into ~30-40 distinct nuclei arranged in anterior, medial, lateral, ventral, posterior, and intralaminar groups
Extensively connected to cerebral cortex via reciprocal thalamocortical and corticothalamic projections
Major nuclei include ventral posterior (sensory relay), ventral lateral/anterior (motor relay), medial dorsal (prefrontal connections), and pulvinar (multimodal integration)
function: Serves as the principal relay station for sensory information (except olfaction) en route to the cerebral cortex
Modulates cortical activity through filtering and gating of information flow via attention mechanisms
Participates in motor control through connections with basal ganglia and cerebellum
Contributes to consciousness, arousal, and sleep-wake cycles through reticular and intralaminar nuclei

5.name: Left Caudate
structure: C-shaped nucleus forming part of the corpus striatum and dorsal striatum of the basal ganglia
Consists of an enlarged head (in the anterior horn of lateral ventricle), body, and tail extending into the temporal lobe
Rich in medium spiny neurons (~95%) containing GABA and either D1 or D2 dopamine receptors
Receives glutamatergic input from cortex and dopaminergic input from substantia nigra pars compacta
function: Forms part of the indirect pathway in basal ganglia circuits that modulate movement
Critical for procedural learning, habit formation, and skill acquisition
Involved in goal-directed behaviors and cognitive flexibility
Dysfunction contributes to movement disorders (Huntington's disease, chorea) and certain psychiatric conditions

6.name: Left Putamen
structure: Large, rounded nucleus forming the lateral part of the lentiform nucleus within the basal ganglia
Located lateral to the globus pallidus and separated from it by the lateral medullary lamina
Contains primarily GABAergic medium spiny neurons with distinct D1 and D2 receptor-expressing populations
Receives input from motor and somatosensory cortices, substantia nigra, and thalamus
function: Plays a central role in regulating movement execution and motor learning
Operates within both direct (facilitatory) and indirect (inhibitory) pathways of motor control
Participates in implicit learning of sequential movements and motor habits
Degeneration contributes to parkinsonian symptoms including bradykinesia and rigidity

7.name: Left Pallidum
structure: Component of the lentiform nucleus divided into external (GPe) and internal (GPi) segments
Contains large GABAergic projection neurons with extensive dendritic arbors
Separated by the internal medullary lamina, a thin sheet of myelinated fibers
Heavily interconnected with striatum, subthalamic nucleus, thalamus, and substantia nigra
function: GPe is a key component of the indirect pathway, providing inhibitory control to the subthalamic nucleus
GPi serves as a major output nucleus of the basal ganglia to the thalamus
Regulates the timing, force, and amplitude of voluntary movements
Target for deep brain stimulation in treatment-resistant Parkinson's disease and dystonia

8.name: Brain Stem
structure: Consists of midbrain, pons, and medulla oblongata, connecting the spinal cord with the diencephalon
Contains ascending sensory tracts, descending motor tracts, and numerous cranial nerve nuclei (III-XII)
Houses vital centers for cardiovascular, respiratory, and arousal regulation
Contains reticular formation, a diffuse network of neurons regulating consciousness and autonomic functions
function: Controls vital physiological functions including respiration, heart rate, blood pressure, and consciousness
Serves as a conduit for all information flow between brain and spinal cord
Mediates reflexes such as coughing, sneezing, vomiting, and pupillary responses
Critical for maintaining posture, balance, and coordinating movements through vestibular nuclei and connections with the cerebellum

9.name: Left Hippocampus
structure: Curved, seahorse-shaped structure located in the medial temporal lobe
Organized into distinct subfields: CA1, CA2, CA3, CA4 (dentate gyrus), and subiculum
Contains a unique trisynaptic circuit: perforant path → dentate gyrus → CA3 → CA1
Exhibits remarkable neuroplasticity, including adult neurogenesis in the dentate gyrus
function: Essential for the formation of new declarative memories (episodic and semantic)
Crucial for spatial navigation and cognitive mapping of environments
Facilitates memory consolidation by transferring information to neocortex during sleep
Dysfunction contributes to amnesia, Alzheimer's disease, post-traumatic stress disorder, and schizophrenia

10.name: Left Amygdala
structure: Almond-shaped collection of nuclei located deep within the medial temporal lobe
Composed of basolateral complex, centromedial nucleus, and cortical nucleus
Extensively connected with hippocampus, prefrontal cortex, hypothalamus, and brainstem
Contains neurons responsive to emotionally salient stimuli and social cues
function: Central role in emotional processing, particularly fear conditioning and threat detection
Mediates autonomic responses associated with emotions (heart rate, respiration, skin conductance)
Critical for emotional memory enhancement and social cognition
Implicated in anxiety disorders, PTSD, and social-emotional processing deficits in autism

11.name: Left Accumbens
structure: Part of the ventral striatum located where the caudate and putamen meet ventrally
Divided into core and shell regions with distinct connectivity and neurochemistry
Rich in dopaminergic terminals from the ventral tegmental area (VTA)
Contains medium spiny GABAergic neurons with D1 and D2 receptors, cholinergic interneurons, and fast-spiking interneurons
function: Key component of the brain's reward circuit, mediating pleasure, motivation, and reinforcement learning
Processes reward prediction errors that drive goal-directed behaviors
Central to addiction mechanisms, including drug seeking and relapse behaviors
Involved in processing of aversion, stress responses, and certain aspects of mood regulation

12.name: Right Cerebral White Matter
structure: Myelinated axonal tracts in the right hemisphere connecting cortical and subcortical regions
Contains projection fibers (internal capsule), commissural fibers (corpus callosum), and association fibers
Demonstrates some asymmetry compared to left hemisphere white matter, particularly in language pathways
Development continues well into the third decade of life with progressive myelination
function: Enables rapid signal transmission and integration within the right hemisphere and between hemispheres
Supports right hemisphere specializations in visuospatial processing, attention, and emotional regulation
Contributes to global aspects of language processing including prosody and pragmatics
Integrity correlates with processing speed, attention, and cognitive efficiency

13.name: Right Cerebral Cortex
structure: Laminated gray matter covering the right cerebral hemisphere with six distinct layers
Shows hemispheric specialization with enhanced development of regions for visuospatial processing
Contains specialized regions including right temporoparietal junction and inferior frontal gyrus
Exhibits structural asymmetries compared to left hemisphere, particularly in planum temporale and parietal regions
function: Specialized for holistic, global processing of visual and spatial information
Dominant for attentional processes, particularly spatial attention and detection of salient stimuli
Critical for aspects of social cognition including facial recognition and emotional processing
Mediates prosodic and pragmatic aspects of language comprehension

14.name: Right Lateral Ventricle
structure: CSF-filled cavity within the right cerebral hemisphere with central body and three horns
Separated from left lateral ventricle by the septum pellucidum
Contains choroid plexus tissue that produces cerebrospinal fluid
Communicates with third ventricle via the right foramen of Monro
function: Contributes to CSF production and circulation throughout the ventricular system
Provides mechanical cushioning and buoyancy for the right hemisphere
Facilitates removal of metabolic waste from the brain parenchyma
Changes in size and shape serve as biomarkers for neurological conditions

15.name: Right Thalamus
structure: Large diencephalic structure with numerous nuclei organized into functional groups
Forms the lateral wall of the third ventricle on the right side
Connected to ipsilateral cortex via thalamocortical and corticothalamic projections
Contains specialized nuclei including lateral geniculate (vision), medial geniculate (audition), and VPL/VPM (somatosensation)
function: Processes and relays sensory information to right hemisphere cortical regions
Participates in attention networks with emphasis on spatial attention to the left visual field
Contributes to arousal and consciousness through reticular activating system connections
Modulates motor output through connections with right motor cortex, basal ganglia, and cerebellum

16.name: Right Caudate
structure: C-shaped striatal nucleus extending from frontal horn to temporal lobe in right hemisphere
Composed primarily of medium spiny GABAergic neurons with D1 or D2 receptors
Receives glutamatergic input from cortex and dopaminergic input from substantia nigra
Participates in cortico-striato-thalamo-cortical loops
function: Contributes to motor control through basal ganglia circuits
Involved in spatial working memory and cognitive flexibility
Participates in stimulus-response learning and habit formation
Right caudate particularly important for spatial navigation and attention to left hemispace

17.name: Right Putamen
structure: Largest nucleus of the basal ganglia, forming lateral part of right lentiform nucleus
Contains primarily GABAergic medium spiny neurons with distinct D1/D2 receptor populations
Receives topographically organized projections from motor and somatosensory cortices
Forms part of the striatum along with the caudate nucleus
function: Regulates movement execution and motor sequences for left side of body
Participates in procedural learning and automatic execution of learned motor sequences
Contributes to both direct (facilitatory) and indirect (inhibitory) motor pathways
Integrates sensorimotor information to modulate appropriate movement parameters

18.name: Right Pallidum
structure: Medial portion of the lentiform nucleus divided into internal (GPi) and external (GPe) segments
Contains large GABAergic neurons with extensive dendritic fields
Segments separated by the internal medullary lamina
Major input nucleus is striatum; major output targets are thalamus and subthalamic nucleus
function: Functions as a major output nucleus of the basal ganglia via GPi projections to thalamus
GPe participates in the indirect pathway, providing inhibitory input to subthalamic nucleus
Critically involved in the timing and scaling of voluntary movements
Dysfunction contributes to movement disorders including Parkinson's disease and dystonia

19.name: Right Hippocampus
structure: Curved structure in right medial temporal lobe with distinct subfields (CA1-4, dentate gyrus)
Organized in a laminar fashion with unique trisynaptic circuit
Connected to other limbic structures including amygdala, entorhinal cortex, and mammillary bodies
Exhibits hemispheric specialization with greater involvement in spatial navigation
function: Crucial for spatial memory, navigation, and environmental mapping
Contributes to episodic memory formation with emphasis on spatial context
Contains place cells that fire when an animal is in specific locations in the environment
Right hippocampal lesions particularly impair recall of visual-spatial material and navigational abilities

20.name: Right Amygdala
structure: Collection of nuclei in right medial temporal lobe with basolateral, centromedial, and cortical divisions
Extensively connected with sensory systems, prefrontal cortex, and hypothalamus
Contains neurons responsive to threatening stimuli and socially relevant information
Exhibits some functional lateralization with right amygdala particularly involved in nonverbal emotional processing
function: Processes emotional stimuli with right-sided bias for negative emotions and nonverbal emotional cues
Mediates autonomic responses to emotional stimuli including stress response
Contributes to emotional memory enhancement and social cognition
Plays role in recognition of emotional facial expressions, particularly fear

21.name: Right Accumbens
structure: Ventral striatal structure in right hemisphere with distinct core and shell subregions
Rich in dopamine receptors and dopaminergic terminals from ventral tegmental area
Contains primarily medium spiny GABAergic neurons with distinct D1 and D2 receptor populations
Connected to limbic structures including amygdala, hippocampus, and prefrontal cortex
function: Key component of the brain's reward circuit mediating reinforcement and motivation
Processes reward prediction errors that guide approach and avoidance behaviors
Involved in hedonic aspects of experiences including natural rewards and drugs of abuse
Contributes to goal-directed behavior and incentive salience
